content.text: \(1 \times 10^{- 3} \text{kg}\) for the mass of a grain of sand
\(1 \times 10^{- 2} \text{m}^3\) for the volume of a tennis ball
\(1 \times 10^{0} \text{J}\) for the work done lifting an apple from waist height to head height
\(1 \times 10^{4} \text{W}\) for the power of a light bulb in a house
Which estimate is reasonable?
C
K
\(\mathrm{^\circ C}\)
\(\mathrm{^\circ K}\)
What is the symbol for the SI base unit of temperature?
A systematic error can be caused by using an incorrectly calibrated instrument
One particular type of systematic error can affect all the measurements by the same amount
The effect of a systematic error can be reduced by repeating and averaging the measurements
Zero error is a type of systematic error
Which statement about systematic errors is **not** correct?
An object is moving with an initial velocity of \(4.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) to the right. The velocity of the object changes so that its final velocity is \(3.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) downwards, as shown
Which arrow represents the change in velocity of the object?
A car travels anticlockwise along a horizontal circular road of radius \(12\mathrm{m}\), as shown
The car takes a time of 4.0 s to move from position P to position Q
What is the magnitude of the average velocity of the car for the journey from P to Q?
The water surface in a deep well is \(78.0 \text{m}\) below the top of the well. A person at the top of the well drops a heavy stone down the well
Air resistance is negligible. The speed of sound in the air is \(330 \text{m s}^{-1}\)
What is the time interval between the person dropping the stone and hearing it hitting the water?
The forces act in opposite directions
The forces act on different objects
The forces act on objects in contact
The forces are of equal magnitude
Which statement is **not** a requirement of a pair of forces that obey Newton's third law of motion?
A child of mass \(20\mathrm{kg}\) stands on the rough surface of a sledge of mass \(40\mathrm{kg}\). The sledge can slide on a horizontal frictionless surface
One end of a rope is attached to the sledge. The rope passes around a fixed frictionless pole, and the other end of the rope is held by the child, as shown
The rope is horizontal. The child pulls on the rope with a horizontal force of \(12\mathrm{N}\). This causes the child and the sledge to move with equal acceleration towards the pole
What is the frictional force between the child and the sledge?
A stone S and a foam rubber ball R are identical spheres of equal volume. They are released from rest at time \(t = 0\) and fall vertically through the air. Both reach terminal velocity
Which graph best shows the variation with time \(t\) of the speed \(v\) of the stone and of the rubber ball?
\(3\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) to the left
\(13\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) to the left
\(3\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) to the right
\(13\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) to the right
Two balls X and Y are moving towards each other with speeds of \(5\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) and \(15\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) respectively
They make a perfectly elastic head-on collision and ball Y moves to the right with a speed of \(7\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\)
What is the speed and direction of ball X after the collision?
They are in the same direction
They are perpendicular to each other
They have the same magnitude
They pass through the same point
Two forces form a couple
Which statement describes the two forces?
A uniform rod is attached by a hinge at one end to a wall. The other end of the rod is supported by a wire so that the rod is horizontal and in equilibrium
Which arrow shows the direction of the force on the rod from the hinge?
1.0 cm
1.6 cm
9.8 cm
16 cm

A diving board of length \(5.0 \text{m}\) is hinged at one end and supported \(2.0 \text{m}\) from this end by a spring of spring constant \(10 \text{kN} \text{m}^{- 1}\). A child of mass \(40 \text{kg}\) stands at the far end of the board
What is the extra compression of the spring caused by the child standing on the end of the board?
A granite rock at the surface of the Earth has density \(\rho\). The rock is transported to the surface of another planet
The acceleration of free fall on the surface of the other planet is twice that on the surface of the Earth
What is the density of the rock on the other planet?
\(p_1 = \rho gy\)
A closed U-shaped tube contains a stationary liquid of density \(\rho\). One side of the tube contains a gas at pressure \(p_1\) and the other side contains a gas at pressure \(p_2\), as shown
The acceleration of free fall is \(g\)
Which equation is correct?
force \(\times\) distance
force \(\times\) velocity
work done \(\times\) time
work done \(\times\) velocity
Which product of two quantities is equal to power?

Researchers have developed a new type of filament lamp with an efficiency of \(40\%\) . Old-type filament lamps have an efficiency of \(5.0\%\) . The two types of lamp produce the same useful output power
What is the ratio \(\frac{\text{input power to new type of lamp}}{\text{input power to old type of lamp}}?\)

A student attempts to derive the formula for kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\). She begins by considering an object of mass \(m\) which is initially at rest. A constant force \(F\) applied to the object causes it to accelerate to final velocity \(v\) in displacement s. The kinetic energy gained by the object is equal to the work done on the object by the force \(F\)
Which equation would the student **not** need in order to derive the formula for \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) ?
A metal wire obeys Hooke's law and has a Young modulus of \(2.0 \times 10^{11} \text{Pa}\). The wire has an original length of \(1.6 \text{m}\) and a diameter of \(0.48 \times 10^{-3} \text{m}\)
What is the spring constant of the wire?
The deformation is plastic after the elastic limit has been reached
The deformation is plastic until the elastic limit is reached
The extension is proportional to the tensile force after the elastic limit has been reached
The extension is proportional to the tensile force until the elastic limit is reached
A wire is being stretched by a tensile force
Which statement about the elastic limit **must** be correct?
The distance from a peak to the next trough is equal to a wavelength
They can be demonstrated in ripple tanks
They consist of vibrating atoms
They transfer energy from one position to another
Which statement is correct for **all** types of progressive wave?

A transverse water wave is moving along the surface of some water. This causes a ball to move vertically without moving horizontally as it floats upon the surface. At one instant, the ball is at the position shown
The wave has a frequency of \(0.20 \text{Hz}\) and an amplitude of \(0.70 \text{m}\). The distance between a trough and an adjacent peak is \(2.4 \text{m}\)
What is the distance travelled by the ball in a time of \(20 \text{s}\)?
A sound wave travels from left to right across a room. The variation with distance across the room of the displacement of the air molecules at one instant is shown
At which distance will the air pressure be lowest?
a source that is moving as it produces the sound wave
a source that produces a polarised sound wave
a source that produces a sound wave of changing amplitude
a source that produces a sound wave of changing frequency
A source emits a sound wave of a single frequency. The Doppler effect causes a different frequency of sound to be heard by a stationary observer
What is a requirement for the Doppler effect to occur?
infrared
microwave
ultraviolet
X-ray
An electromagnetic wave in free space has a frequency of \(2.5 \times 10^{14} \text{Hz}\)
Which region of the electromagnetic spectrum includes this frequency?
zero
Two polarising filters are placed next to each other so that their planes are parallel
The first polarising filter has its transmission axis at an angle of \(50^{\circ}\) to the vertical
The second polarising filter has its transmission axis at an angle of \(20^{\circ}\) to the vertical. The angle between the transmission axes of the two polarising filters is \(30^{\circ}\)
A beam of vertically polarised light of intensity \(8.0 \text{W} \text{m}^{-2}\) is incident normally on the first polarising filter
What is the intensity of the light that is transmitted from the second polarising filter?
Point R is at a node
Points Q and S vibrate in phase
The distance between P and T is three wavelengths
The wave transfers energy from P to T
A stationary wave on a stretched string is set up between two points P and T
Which statement about the stationary wave is correct?
A bar vibrates with frequency \(f\) to produce water waves in a ripple tank
The waves pass through a gap of width \(x\) in a barrier so that diffraction occurs
Which combination of vibration frequency and gap width will produce the smallest angle of diffraction?
An outdoor concert has two large speakers beside the stage for broadcasting music
In order to test the speakers, they are made to emit sound of the same wavelength and the same amplitude
The curved lines in the diagram represent wavefronts
Where is the loudest sound heard?
The equation
is used to calculate the wavelength \(\lambda\) of light in an experiment that uses a diffraction grating. The light from the diffraction grating is displayed on a screen
What do the symbols \(n\) and \(d\) represent?

table.html:
\(n\)\(d\)
Anumber of slits in the gratingdistance between adjacent slits in the grating
Bnumber of slits in the gratingdistance from grating to screen
Corder of intensity maximumdistance between adjacent slits in the grating
Dorder of intensity maximumdistance from grating to screen

content.text: \(I = nqabc\)
\(I = \frac{nqV}{t}\)
\(I = \frac{nqbc}{t}\)
\(I = nqav\)
The diagram shows a metal block

The block has sides of length \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) as shown, and its volume is \(V.\) Each charge carrier has a charge \(-q\) and the number density of the charge carriers in the metal is \(n.\) It takes each charge carrier an average time of \(t\) to pass through the block
What is an expression for the current \(I?\)

The circuit diagrams show two lamps X and Y each connected to a cell. The current in lamp X is \(0.50 \text{A}\) and its resistance is \(9.6 \Omega\). The current in lamp Y is \(3.0 \text{A}\) and its resistance is \(1.2 \Omega\)
What is the ratio \(\frac{\text{power in lamp X}}{\text{power in lamp Y}}\)?

The intensity of light incident on a light-dependent resistor (LDR) is increased. The temperature of a thermistor is increased. In each case, the current in the component is maintained at a constant value
What happens to the potential difference across each component?
R
R
An iron wire has length \(8.0 \text{m}\) and diameter \(0.50 \text{mm}\). The wire has resistance \(R\)
A second iron wire has length \(2.0 \text{m}\) and diameter \(1.0 \text{mm}\)
What is the resistance of the second wire?
a decrease in the charge of each charge carrier
a decrease in the potential difference measured across the cell
an increase in the energy dissipated per unit time in the fixed resistor
an increase in the number of charge carriers leaving the cell per unit time
A cell with constant electromotive force (e.m.f.) is connected across a fixed resistor. Over time, the internal resistance of the cell increases
Which change occurs as the internal resistance of the cell increases?
Kirchhoff's first and second laws are consequences of the conservation of different quantities
What are those quantities?

A potentiometer circuit is used to determine the electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(E_{\mathrm{x}}\) of a cell. The circuit includes a second cell of known e.m.f. \(E_{0}\) and negligible internal resistance, and a uniform resistance wire PQ of known length
\(E_{\mathrm{x}}\) is less than \(E_{0}\)
The movable connection J can be positioned anywhere along the length of the resistance wire
Which circuit is suitable for determining \(E_{\mathrm{x}}\) ?
Atoms are mostly empty space
Most of the mass of an atom is concentrated in the nucleus
The nucleus of an atom contains protons
The nucleus of an atom is small compared to the size of an atom

In an experiment on \(\alpha \)-particle scattering, \(\alpha \)-particles are directed at a thin gold foil. Most of the \(\alpha \)-particles pass straight through the foil or are deflected by a small angle. A small number of \(\alpha \)-particles are deflected by a large angle
Which statement **cannot** be deduced from this experiment?
An uncharged atom of element Q has 24 orbital electrons
Nuclei G and M are isotopes of the same element
When E absorbs a neutron and then emits an \(\alpha\)-particle, E transforms into M
When M emits a \(\beta^{- }\) particle, M transforms into Q
Four nuclei are represented below
Which statement about these nuclei is correct?
d \(\rightarrow\) u + \(\beta^{- }\) + \(\nu_{\mathrm{e}}\)
d \(\rightarrow\) u + \(\beta^{- }\) + \(\overline{\nu}_{\mathrm{e}}\)
u \(\rightarrow\) d + \(\beta^{+} + \nu_{\mathrm{e}}\)
u \(\rightarrow\) d + \(\beta^{+} + \overline{\nu}_{\mathrm{e}}\)
A neutron is composed of one up (u) quark and two down (d) quarks. When a neutron decays to a proton, a beta-particle is emitted
What is the change in the quark structure of the neutron due to the emission of the beta-particle?
(The symbol for a neutrino is \(\nu_{\mathrm{e}}\) and for an antineutrino is \(\overline{\nu}_{\mathrm{e}}\) .)
